content: Is these two Windows PCs? If so, assuming you did not change default physical file locations, do this: - exit TB on old PC - copy c:\isers\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to external media - install TB on new PC if not already done. Be sure to NOT be running TB at this time - copy the backed up thunderbird folder from the external media to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming on new PC, overlaying existing files. - restart TB and all should be there.
creator: davidsk

content: Please understand, Thunderbird is but a simple email client. It takes setup information you provide and uses that to send email requests for your account. It then waits and receives whatever messages come back from the server and displays to the user. In some cases, the email provider (in this case, Google) wants to re-verify the user's access to the account and that would explain the prompt. Has the account stopped working?
creator: davidsk

content: connecting to server is not the same as having the wrong password. Please post the exact error message you are receiving. It may also help to post a screenshot of your incoming server settings pane. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content:
For what it's worth, the problem seems to be isolated to the "Inbox" file or the "Inbox.msf" file.

If I delete those two files from the %APPDATA%\Thunderbird\Profiles\4jkcgthm.default\Mail\mail.notlimited.com folder, Thunderbird starts up just fine. It's missing the 6 years or so of emails that were in the Inbox, but at least it opens and allows me to move forward.

The "Inbox" file seems to be a straight forward concatenation of all of the emails with a " From - (?<datetime-retrieved>.*)$"seperator at the top of each message.

I'll write a little program to validate the 46.6GB Inbox file, but I don't think that's the problem.

Although the (misleading and unhelpful) error message indicates the Inbox is opened by another program, evidence indicates that something is wrong with the .msf file. (Or maybe the contents of the Inbox file have exceeded some internal limit, but I suspect that's not the issue.)

Here are the bad and good versions of the two .msf files: 

   Inbox.msf (good):  https://pastebin.com/cjCGXcVu    Inbox.msf (bad):   https://pastebin.com/vYeR2f5H

Here is a diff between the good and the bad .msf files:

``` 21c21 < <(80=1)(81=0)(82=12a20000)(85=59414)(86=6668f3ca)> --- > <(80=1)(81=0)(82=12a20000)(83=b1bc9a4fc)(84=6668a88c)> 23c23 < [1(^AB=1)(^AC=0)(^AD=1)(^A3^82)(^A0=0)(^A1=0)(^A2^85)(^A4^86)]} --- > [1(^AB=1)(^AC=0)(^AD=1)(^A3^82)(^A0=0)(^A1=0)(^A2^83)(^A4^84)]} ```
creator: mark.moore2

content:
mark.moore2 said
For what it's worth, the problem seems to be isolated to the "Inbox" file or the "Inbox.msf" file. If I delete those two files from the %APPDATA%\Thunderbird\Profiles\4jkcgthm.default\Mail\mail.notlimited.com folder, Thunderbird starts up just fine. It's missing the 6 years or so of emails that were in the Inbox, but at least it opens and allows me to move forward. The "Inbox" file seems to be a straight forward concatenation of all of the emails with a " From - (?<datetime-retrieved>.*)$"seperator at the top of each message. I'll write a little program to validate the 46.6GB Inbox file, but I don't think that's the problem.

Sounds like you are using pop accounts. The size could definitely be a problem - 46gb is excessive. 10gb would be more reasonable.

You should be archiving messages out of the Inbox after some period of time. Or deleting.
creator: wsmwk

content:
> There is no other process using the Inbox folder.

Actually there must be. That is exactly what is meant by "Unable to open the folder Inbox on xxx@example.com because it is in use by some other operation. Please wait for that operation to finish and then select the folder again."

Reducing Inbox size may help. But the cause is probably antivirus software, the compact process, or multiple pop accounts going to the same Inbox. Are you using a shared Inbox for multiple pop accounts?
creator: wsmwk
